utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everybody and happy Halloween. I'm Jesse Watters along with Jedediah Bila, Juan Williams, Judge Jeanine Pirro, and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City, and this is "The Five." In just six days, voters head to the polls to decide who'll control congress and the critical midterm elections. This as President Trump kicks off his final campaign blitz in the key state of Florida, where Bernie Sanders will also be holding a dueling rally. The president confident about Republicans chances on Tuesday.

utterances.speaker: DONALD TRUMP, PRESIDENT OF THE UNITED STATES OF AMERICA
utterances.utterance: It seems that the campaign is going very well, looks like we're doing very, very well in the senate. A lot of seats that were not really being thought of in terms of victories a year ago now are looking like they could very well be victories. And the house is -- a lot of people. I mean, there are a lot of people. And I think we're going to do well in the house also. But I know we're doing well in the senate and it looks like we're doing OK in the house.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Trump also issuing a new warning about what will happen if Democrats take the house.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: If the midterms, for some reason, don't do so well for Republicans, I think you're all going to lose a lot of money. I hate to say that. I think you're going to lose a lot of money. People are waiting on their 401K's and everything else. They're waiting to see what happens with the midterms.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Meanwhile, Democrat Nancy Pelosi already taking a victory lap, predicting her party has the house in the bag. REP. NANCY PELOSI, Dâ€”CALIF.: Up until Tuesday, I would have said if the election were held today, we would win.

utterances.speaker: STEPHEN COLBERT, COMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: What happened today that changed that?

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: Now I'm saying is we will win.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: We will win.

utterances.speaker: COLBERT
utterances.utterance: Please don't say that. Do you want to say that on Hillary's fireworks barge? Please don't say that.

utterances.speaker: PELOSI
utterances.utterance: We will win. We own the ground. We're not yielding one grain of sand.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Wow. And yes, she guaranteed victory, the Democrats did in 2016, too. Didn't turn out so well. What do you think about Pelosi's prediction, judge?

utterances.speaker: JEANINE PIRRO, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: I don't think much of Pelosi. I was struck there. I mean, look, they use Hollywood celebrities all the time. It didn't matter. They were huge celebrities. Hillary thought she was a celebrity. The president went out and campaign for Hillary. And in the end, it didn't matter. Barbra Streisand said she was moving to Canada. Now she's threatening to move to Canada again.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They always say that.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: They always say that, but in the end, look, the Republicans care about their money. The president is right. And I think though there's a little trouble in the house.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, I mean, it sounded like the president wasn't as confident in the house as he was in the senate, Greg. What do you make about his tone there?

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: Well, first, if Streisand moves to Canada, I hear Canada is moving to New Zealand.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Here's what I think, both sides are doing the same thing right now. They're railing up the base. They're like motivational speakers who tell you the worst possible scenario. Don't do that to me. So, if Trump wins the left says that granny is going to be pushed off a cliff, they're going to take her social security, and the white men are going to put little boys in cages, right? And then -- but if Trump wins the left says, oh, all caravans are welcome and English will be ban in high school. So it's like everybody is doing -- neither reality is actually true. What they're doing is they're creating a broad, based assumption, based on the stereotypes and they're both doing it, so they're both guilty.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's true. And Trump's tactic could be a little more true than some of the other worse scare tactics like Greg mentioned, the economy, Juan. I mean, you've just had 3.1 percent wage growth this year, highest in a decade, consumer confidence highest since 1998. And someone very smart on Cavuto's show just said this and I'm going to take credit for it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They say that in 1988 it was the last time consumer confidence was this high, and Bill Clinton's party did very well in those midterm elections. How do you see the economy playing in this year's midterms?

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, FOX NEWS HOST
utterances.utterance: I think it's pretty obvious. The Republicans can't run on it, that's why the president has to resort to fear and loathing and make it fright night Halloween early with, I'm sending troops to the border. Oh, there's a caravan approaching. Gangsters, MS- 13, terrorists, oh, disease is approaching the border and I'm sending the troops to stop -- what kind of madness is this? Greg is right. There's a lot of things are being said that just aren't true.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I said both sides, Juan. I was being fair.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, but I'm not being fair.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'll tell you why I'm not being fair because there's no analogous action by the Democrats. What you have is President Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, of course there is.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Democrats said there's going to be a civil war and he's Hitler, and he's going to lock up.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think Democrats are saying a civil war.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Blood on the streets.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Blood on the streets. We're taking the social security.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought people are upset about Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Jedediah, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: JEDEDIAH BILA, HOST
utterances.utterance: I mean, Democrats are always talking about health care as the chief issue. Running -- everyone's health care is going to be taken away. So what are we even talking about?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Hold on. Wait a minute. Isn't it true that Republicans promise that once they took over, they would repeal and replace.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You're saying that's not a scare tactic?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what Republican -- and Republicans haven't done anything. And only belatedly now is the president saying, oh, if you have pre-existing conditions, I'd consider. He's late to the game.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Late in the game, are you kidding, Juan?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, go right ahead.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: The economy, consumer confidence.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We were talking about health care.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yeah, but you know what? With health care, he got rid of the individual mandate. Come on.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, in other words, that's why Democrats are running ads and why they're having success by saying to Americans right now that health care system is in jeopardy under Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So when they use fear tactics, they're telling the truth? But when anyone else -- social security for one, also talking about how evil Trump is, how racist and insane he is. That's fear tactic.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's not a fear tactic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: When the truth is told you call it fear tactic on the left.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm just pointing out what you just did.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Why is he crazy to be talking about securing the border? I mean, that's.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse and I have been over this a thousand times.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Remember when Obama, remember when other people put in additional security at the border, I'm all for it.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And the reason the economy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The caravan has nothing to do with border security.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Let's move on. Hollywood is doing whatever it can to get off the vote. Oprah is hitting the campaign trail tomorrow in Georgia to stump for Democratic gubernatorial candidate, Stacey Abrams. Taylor Swift posted that she's voting for Democrat Phil Bredesen in the Tennessee senate race, and is urging fans to not sit this one out. So, Greg, now celebrities getting involved. Oprah, you know, I mean.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oprah is different than the Alyssa Milano's, and the Will Ferrell's.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She's an icon.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. And she -- you trust what she has to say. I do believe though that the negative impact of a moralizing celebrity of limited intellect -- I'm not talking about Oprah, cancels the positive impact of their famous space. So when you have somebody who is, kind of a newbie, when someone gets into politics as a celebrity, they're stunted. It's like their politics is back where they were when they decided to chase fame. So their politics are that of like a 17-year-old.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Like Taylor Swift.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah. Because for ten years, ten years, they've been all about themselves, so finally they feel guilty about this and then they go, I'm going to become politically aware. But they're back where they were when they stopped reading.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yeah. But it's even worse than that, Greg. It's not like just ten years. It's the fact that -- what do they do for a living? They don't think. They memorize the lines that other people write.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, we kind of do that too.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Everybody has a right to an opinion, but we have to be able to analyze and say where are they in the road to life?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: What do they know? What is their experience? What is it based on? I'm famous so therefore, you know, believe me and everybody in my ilk.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Greg writes his own line because he's got piles of notes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I didn't even get to my notes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm curious about this analysis because a couple weeks ago you guys told me Kanye West, oh, he's great. Oh, he's so smart. Talk about a Halloween surprise.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That has nothing to do with his stance on Trump.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Back when he was 17 and knew nothing. How about Donald Trump? He's a celebrity politician.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: What people was ascending was the right of Kanye West to have an opinion.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're attacking him for other reasons, Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Kanye West -- oval office using profanity, Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And Republicans loved it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I will say no one on this side called Oprah or any of these other Taylor Swift people mentally ill.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: No one said a lot of disgusting things about anybody for endorsing anybody.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What are you talking about?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Kanye West suffered some of the most horrible rhetoric I've ever seen about anyone on television, besides me, and he didn't deserve it, OK. And that came from your side.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, yeah, the guy has bipolar disorder by his own admission.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, that's mean. You have another disorder it's called Trump derangement syndrome.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no, no.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The birthright citizenship battle rages on as Democratic hypocrisy on this issue is exposed. We'll see it next.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: President Trump not backing down from the growing battle over birthright citizenship.

utterances.speaker: TRUMP
utterances.utterance: I believe that you can have a simple vote in Congress or it's even possible, in my opinion, this is after meeting with some very talented legal scholars, that you can do it through an executive order. Now, I'd rather do it through congress because that's permanent. If president Obama could get DACA approved, certainly we can do DACA, we can do this by executive order. The Democrats have left immigration in our country get out of control with their horrible, not allowing us to have any votes to get passage.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The president and conservatives are pointing out Harry Reid's comments about these very issue from 25 years ago.

utterances.speaker: HARRY REID, FORMER SENATOR
utterances.utterance: If making it easy to be an illegal alien isn't enough, how about offering a reward for being an illegal immigrant? No sane country would do that, right? Guess again. If you break our laws by entering this country without permission to give birth to a child, we reward that child with U.S. citizenship and guarantee a full access to all public and social services this society provides, and that's a lot of services.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So, senator -- or former Senator Reid issued a statement today saying he was wrong then and President Trump is wrong now. Judge Jeanine?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Well, first of all, there are three questions here. Number one, what is the Constitution says? The Constitution says if you're born or naturalized here and subject to the jurisdiction, you're a citizen. So then the question is, have the courts apply this? The courts have only ruled on one case and that involved a guy by the name of Juan Kemp, who was a Chinese legal resident alien. They've had a baby -- the couple had a baby who was born here. The Supreme Court said, 30-years-later, after the 14th Amendment, no problem. They are legal resident aliens, ergo that child can be considered for automatic birthright. The most important thing for people to consider when they talk about birthright citizenship is the context with the words 14th Amendment which ratified in 1868. It was right after the Civil War. It was during the construction period where they wanted to make sure that the slaves were given the ability to be citizens and to vote, all right? So that's the context that it came in. Now, there is no question that no other country in the world grants automatic citizenship.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wait a second, what about Mexico and Canada?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Mexico and Canada, it's not automatic. What you've got to do is you've got have a parent who has been in that country for a period of time, not someone like in Los Angeles where two-thirds of the babies born in county run hospitals are born to illegal immigrants who just got there. That's the difference. So you cannot say that any other country in the world does this. And I think the third most important thing is not just the cost, it cost us billions because as a Supreme Court ruled a few years back any illegal, any child born here who was born here is entitled to education and health care and all that other stuff. So it will cost us billions. How do we change this? Number one, someone can take a court case up. Number two, congress can pass an act. Or number three, the president can do an executive order. But I think -- and I'm going to end here, the most significant part of this is section five of the 14th Amendment says congress has the power to enforce by appropriate legislation any provisions of this article. So they recognize that in a time when you could not anticipate illegals coming in, where the only issue in context where the slaves. And, by the way, they left out the American Indians, do you know why? Because they have jurisdiction, they're under the jurisdiction of tribal lands.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. Well it sounded like -- you said a lot.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'm glad my notes helped you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, she stole your notes.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: No, I didn't.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But all you've said, judge, comes down to I think what Paul Ryan says. Jedediah, Paul Ryan said you can't do this unless you change the Constitution and he doesn't see that. And then, today, the president went after Paul Ryan and attack Paul Ryan, told him to shut up.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I actually -- whether or not you can do it by executive orders is up for debate. I actually would recommend that he not do it by executive order for the same reason that I advocated that -- President Obama not do.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what Paul Ryan said.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And the reason also is that even if the policy makes sense then for the time in question, people will automatically demonize you because of the way that you went about it by executive order. So I think.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: He's going to do both.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You have to be able to ask questions about whether -- everybody is demonized all the time for just asking a question. You have to be able to look at a policy and say the way that this was dreamed up does not fit society as it stands now. So should this be a policy that should be happening now? Should it be that someone can come over illegally with the sole intent of wanting to give birth to a baby that then have automatic citizenship and gains access to a bunch of benefits that citizens get here. You have to be able to question that. That doesn't mean you can write executive -- make a change, necessarily, but it does mean that the topic becomes up for debate. And the people who brought that topic up should not automatically be demonized.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Nobody is demonizing, but I think.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It happens all the time. He's already been demonized.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But, Jesse, you're the king of what about-ism.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, I've got a good one for this.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Because you've got Harry Reid, 25-years-ago, he said he's changed his mind, but the fact is Harry Reid did, in fact, support doing away with birthright.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The reason he changed his mind is not because he had a change of heart. He changed his mind because the AFL-CIO change their position on illegal immigration because they wanted more Hispanics to come over here so they could pay union dues and fill up those roles. Now, here's somewhat- about-ism, Juan. I do find it funny how liberals believe that illegal aliens crossing the border and having American babies is enshrined in our Constitution, but the right to bear arms isn't enshrined in our Constitution, major hypocrisy there. Excellent job summarizing the legal thing. The only thing I would add is what I said yesterday, the drafter of the 14th Amendment, Jacob Howard, said this should not apply to persons in the United States who are foreigners and aliens. This is a big issue because nearly 10 percent of babies born in this country are from illegal aliens. But, you have to combine this with the law and eliminating the lottery and eliminating the chain migration because right now it's out of control.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: OK. So, you know, we've had filibusters. Now I turned to Greg Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well -- OK, I'll summarize in human terms, OK, 290,000 births from this kind of -- I don't know what you'd call it, but it's a dramatic leap over the past decade. And the reason is word travels fast when there is a loophole. This is true in every part of life. When in high school when you heard that some parents went away, everybody knew that's where you went to party, right?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So when people know that you can get free alcohol at somebody's house, you go. I don't blame -- what I'm saying is, I don't blame people for seeking out a loophole. I blame the people who don't fix the system once they know the loophole is there. And I think Donald Trump understands how people see unfairness in this because he's always about reciprocity and fairness. And you get angry. The most fundamental human anger is when somebody cuts in front of you. The thing that drives me crazy, when you try to get from the airport to the rental car agency and you get on the tram and the last person on gets to be the first person in line at the rental car agency. I don't think I ever get as mad as I get at that point. When I go, I've been waiting here for 20 minutes and this guy -- then all of a sudden, he's first in line. That's bogus. And I think that Trump understands that emotion and it's very real, very human.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That reminds me. I just have to confess something. I cut a hundred people in the TSA line the other day. I'm sorry. I'm sorry, I was going to miss a flight.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think we didn't discuss the fact that, of course, this issue comes up now, few days before the midterms, because Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Who started the caravan, Juan? Your side.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Up next, Ben & Jerry, yeah, the ice cream guys joining the resistance by serving up a new flavor of ice cream, anti-Trump ice cream. That's next on The Five.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Ben & Jerry's has a new ice cream flavor dedicated to the resistance, and like the resistance, it contains nuts. I know it's too easy. But here's another example of how the left injects politics into everything. Remember when politics stayed in its ugly little lane? Now it's all over the place. It's in sports. It's in movies, your desert. That's what happens when you decide that the personal is now political. You can't escape it. Look at the label. Maybe it's me, but I prefer not to be glared at while eating ice cream. I get that at home without the curtain. But thanks to the left, keeping politics out of regular life is seen as complicit to evil. If you don't join our mad crusade, you're the problem too. Now, I bet this stuff tastes good but who cares. The company says that by purchasing this glop, you will be supporting, quote, groups who are fighting President Trump's regressive agenda. But they should add while also adding to your deadly obesity because isn't that what Ben & Jerry's does? They speak calories to power. According to the NIH, obesity -- being overweight leads to 300,000 deaths per year in the U.S. That's second only to smoking. The math is simple. If obesity kills that many people a year and ice cream makes you obese, how large a role does Ben & Jerry's play in this? Aren't they part of the problem? They're like overweight Marlboro man. Maybe that's why they play up the activism. They want you to think their heart is in the right place as they're busy clogging yours. All right, judge, this doesn't make me want to eat ice cream. I like it to be fun.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: OK, I have to confess.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I love Cherry Garcia. And you know what I did, I went from the ice cream to the Ben & Jerry's Cherry Garcia yogurt.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right. Really?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Here's something for you. I'm never eating it again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Why would they alienate me? Why go out of you way to alienate people who are giving you money? Maybe you don't need my money. Good, I'll go to Haagen-Dazs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: There you go, Haagen-Dazs.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: That's interesting though because I always think that too. Why would you marginalize half the country? But people say this polarization of products really works.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Really?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Yeah. They've been -- Ben & Jerry's has been so political for so long. They endorsed Bernie Sanders. They endorsed same-sex marriage in Vermont with a special ice cream flavor.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Right. So if it wasn't financially working for them.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You do know your ice cream.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I love ice cream.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I feel like they would know that if it wasn't working. And people say that this works.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think people pay attention. I mean, one of these groups has Linda Sarsour involved who was just a notorious anti-Semitic.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- said awful things about people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, they're like the Nike of ice cream. They've alienated half their customer base. In order to make this segment fun, I've created my own ice cream flavors. These are anti-liberal flavors.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Are you ready?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Abolish ICE-cream.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Strzok chocolate, Peter Strzok. Mooch tracks, you know, Scaramucci. It took Juan awhile.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't think Scaramucci is going to appreciate that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, this one for you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Never mind. Nougat Gingrich. Ready? It gets better.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Second Amend-mint.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Make America grape again.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Very good.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I've got more. Two more.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, two more.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Crooked and cream.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Nice.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Last one. Fondue junior, like Don Jr.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How about -- how about Caravan-illa?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Or how about this, Raisin -- How about this? Raisin Awareness?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I like it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's the way they should have gone. I like that one.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Raisin Awareness.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It just took me an hour. You came up with two like that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Juan -- Juan, are you going to go buy this ice cream? Because I know you have a sweet tooth.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I love it, but I don't know what the flavor's like. So we'll see.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's Pecans. It's pecan.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You'll love pecans. They're delicious.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How do you pronounce "pecan"?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Pe-cahn.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Then it doesn't work. It's Pecan Resist, like "we can resist." Instead, if it's "Pe-cahn Resist," it makes no s

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I've got a question for you about the monologue. Was that a spoof?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: When you're saying about, "Oh -- leading people to obesity"?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, 300,000 people die a year from obesity. And ice cream --

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So what are you going to say -- what are you going to say to Papa John's? He's a right-wing nut. He's selling obesity.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know what? When he starts putting it in his product, I'll say something.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He does. He says horrible things.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't know anything on his packaging that -- by the way, I don't eat Papa John's. I don't eat pizza. I don't eat any pizza. There are certain dietary issues that we can't get into here.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Do you eat ice cream?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not any more. Not now. Not since this happened. I iced to have ice cream for breakfast.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: And I have pizza for breakfast.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think, though, judge, because you are a fan of Ben & Jerry's, I think you should get a vat of Chubby Hubby for your friend there, Donald Trump. Chubby Hubby.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes, that's mean. That is mean. And you know what? Donald Trump is going to be dancing on election night.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Which election? I think he was. I think that's already happened.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This really is their penance, right? Because they know that they're contributing to the death of people. Right? They know they're contributing to the death of people from obesity.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I thought you were joking.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's obviously A plus B plus C.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Ice cream contributes to the death of people?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Of course. It's a conspiracy theory.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You were the one that said tax cuts were going to make people die.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I forgot that. What did I say? What did I say?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You and Nancy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Is there anybody in my ear these days, or you guys take the day off? I just haven't heard anybody. A liberal comedian is calling out the media for how they cover Trump. That's ahead.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: We know President Trump President Trump isn't afraid of calling out fake news, but what's refreshing is when you hear someone like liberal comedian Jon Stewart criticize the media for how they cover the president. Watch this.

utterances.speaker: JON STEWART, COMEDIAN
utterances.utterance: I think the journalists have taken it personally. They're personally wounded and offended by this man. He baits them, and they dive in. And what he's done well, I thought, is appeal to their own narcissism, to their own ego. Because what he says is these are -- and the journalists stand up and say, "We are noble. We are honorable. How dare you, sir?" And they take it personally. And now he's changed the conversation.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: So, Juan, you put your head up first.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I did?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: So what do you -- what do you think of the fact that the -- Jon Stewart is saying that the media, they feel so aggrieved by Donald Trump winning the presidency that they feel that, you know, they have the right to attack. And Stewart is saying, "But wait a minute. This is how you're making your money."

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow, that was an interesting interpretation that you had, because I heard something different. I heard him say that, in fact, the press reacts to Donald Trump personally.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That they take it as an insult to their profession.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: And there are many journalists who feel it's a priesthood, and they are all about facts and the truth. Donald Trump is like, "Great. If you want to engage on that level, I'll go at you, because I'll be anti- media, 'enemy of the people,' and my base will react, like all the elite media and the elites in Hollywood." So but I think, by the way, Jon Stewart is onto something. And I've heard this from others, including Chris Wallace, who say, "You know what? You've got to back away. Maybe you shouldn't engage Trump, because it just feeds the fire.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Jesse, do you think the fact that Donald Trump is fighting with the media, because he believes that a lot of it is fake news, that what he's don't is he's given himself the opportunity to kind of almost avoid talking about things, because now it's about a fight. It's about, like, road -- when something happens on the road, everybody is rubbernecking. They'd rather watch the fight. And as if Donald Trump doesn't get enough air time, just by virtue of being Donald Trump, they continue to fight with him, so it's all about Trump.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Great point. And the country loves watching people battle, and they love watching the media take it on the chin. Because the media is not very well-liked in this country, and when they whine and complain, the rest of the hardworking Americans that work with their hands and take care of their kids and have tough jobs and don't love their jobs like the media do, they look at these people in the front row with Sarah Sanders whining and complaining and preening, and they think, "Are you serious? Am I supposed to feel sorry for you? Absolutely not." And now, what's happened is Donald Trump has won the war against the media. Right now, only 13 percent of the American people believe the media covers both sides accurately. Right now, 33 percent think fake news is the enemy of the American people. And in the last poll, CNN was ranked dead last as the least trusted name in news. So right now, Trump is winning the war on the media, and the media doesn't even realize it.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: All right. But network coverage is now more -- so hostile to Republicans. It's something like 88 percent negative on Republicans. So is this -- are they reacting so negatively that they're taking it out on every Republican in the country?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I don't think that's much different. They would have done the same to Mitt Romney, John McCain, George Bush, you name it. They don't like Republicans. They're about 80 to 90 percent Democrats.

utterances.speaker: Stewart is right, though. If you want the media to focus on you, the easiest thing you could do is mention them. They're notoriously self-obsessed and thin-skinned. You've got to look at, like, Cuomo's Instagram. Oh, my God. You could be summarized in two words
utterances.utterance: love me. But I like -- I am guilty. I love poking the media, because it's like a self-driving car. All you've got to do is press the button and get in the back seat. Get in the back seat, and their insecurities do all the work. Right now, CNN is just ripping Fox News, because they see Fox News as a proxy for America. They can't stop. But what's worse than fake news, I always believe, is the fink news. Do you know what the fink news is?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Those are commentators and web sites whose sole job is to watch you work for a living, and then they wait for you to say something that they can misinterpret, right, and then they use that to hurt you. They'll put that up on their site. It's the lowest job in media, and if you have that job, quit.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Well, how do you spell that?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: How do you spell what? Fink? F-I-N-K.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: OK, so what do you think of the finks? Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You know, I think the media is not used to being challenged by a Republican politician, and it shows. And they're used to, you know, President Bush took the high road on this a lot of times. He didn't pick on them when they were picking on him. They're not used to it. I do think Trump has to walk a fine line here, though, and I think he is talking about fake news when he talks about the enemy of the people. But he needs to make sure he clarifies that do a good job, are fair. But those that are completely, totally biased all the time cannot handle that someone is willing to say, "You are completely and totally biased all the time." And that's where the pushback is happening.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Greg said that the -- CNN's attacking Fox because we're a proxy for America. Trump is attacking the media, because they're a proxy for the Democratic Party. And no other Republican politician has done that before. And Juan was saying, "Oh, you know, the media is so obsessed with facts." There's a litany of things they've gotten wrong under this president, and it's not based on -- it's not based on, you know, errors and mistakes; they're rushing. It's not sloppy. It's driven by hate. And when you hate, you make mistakes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, yes, so the caravan, oh, those are terrible people coming towards us. Those are invaders.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: But they said it was all women and children, Juan. It's actually all young men.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what? This is so ridiculous.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: You know what, Juan? You keep -- you keep referring to the caravan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, how about --

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Are you ready to stand up and say every one of them is going to be nice?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No, but that's not the issue.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Well, that is the issue.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: This is a fake issue, created by a politician who --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- by liberal activists. It was ginned up by liberal activists.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, ginned up. Oh, stop.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And it blew up in their face. Just like the Kavanaugh hearings blew up in their face.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what almost blew up in our face? The bombs that were created by a guy who was a big --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The caravan, let's send to Juan's house. Juan's going to take them all in. Right, Juan? You have a big place, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, yes, yes. There you go. Democracy.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: All right, good. All right. It's time for some fun and, of course, lots of candy but no ice cream. We're celebrating Halloween, next on "The Five."

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: It's Halloween.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: We are celebrating Halloween with a ton of candy and a bunch of fun stories. So first up, there's a nationwide push to permanently move Halloween from October 31 to the last Saturday of the month. Thousands have signed a petition urging the White House to shift the annual holiday to the weekend so it's safer and more stress-free. What do you think about that, Judge, moving it? I don't know. I have mixed emotions.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I grew up in upstate New York. OK? It's really cold up there. In Elmira, New York, if any of you have ever heard of it. My mom is still there. Hi, Mom. So we -- I always had to wear a winter coat over my costume, because it snowed most of the time. I think they ought to move it to July.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: That's big. That's going to be a big shift.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You can't wear a mask in July. I know if Trump ends up switching the Halloween, the liberals are going to go nuts, because Trump did it. So I don't think it's going to get them any credit. Plus, I like the idea. So if a Halloween falls on a weeknight, like Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, people still celebrate and go nuts on the Saturday preceding it. So then you get two Halloweens, kind of, if you're down.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: But what if you're a parent who works during the week, and you can't take your kids out for trick-or-treating? I think they're doing it for the parents just as much. Because if it's on Saturday, you have the whole day to yourself. You can make a day of it. You're not so stressed out. Coming home from work, rushing around, trying to get the kids ready.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's a good idea.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You think so?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, I mean, to me it's just kind of an invented thing when we do it. So do it at a convenient time. But I must say, I think that for the kids, the kids like the idea that they go out, and you know, that it's unpredictable. That it's all of a sudden time to go. I've got to get out of here. That's pretty much fun for kids.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You know, Greg, a study recently --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A study, eh?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: -- showed 86 percent of parents steal their kids' Halloween candy. This seems to me like something that you might be guilty of.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, no, no. But No. 1, I think Halloween is nothing more than Christmas for Satanists. Let's be obvious about this, all right?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: To ruin Halloween.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a bunch of pagan rituals by godless heathens. This, by the way, is the longest Halloween ever.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Aren't you a godless heathen?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: This is the longest Halloween ever, OK?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Because it's on Wednesday. I've had -- I've had to endure holiday parties on Friday, Saturday. For some reason, it skipped on Sunday. And then last night and now tonight. It's as though we keep repeating the same stupid, lame segments. I mean, how many times I were going to talk about Halloween and stupid candy? I'm tired of it.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Wait a minute. I love it. I mean, when I had kids, I was working. It was a nightmare. Day out of school.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a pagan holiday for Satanists.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Yes, but then what you do is you raid their pumpkin, and you take the Junior Mints.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Right. Take all the good candy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And what's with mutilating these gourds? These are like -- what have these pumpkins done to you? Mutilating a gourd. That's what we're doing to these pumpkins. Where are the vegetable rights e?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: -- talking about the political segment.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I'm going to buy you a "Get Off My Lawn" T-shirt, and that's what you can wear next time.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I'll get off your lawn. Because they'll be on my lawn.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're upset about everything. For a second, I thought you were going to blame the Democrats for Halloween.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I know. It's coming.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, you know what? You guys do wear a lot of costumes. You pretend to be compassionate, and you pretend to be smart. You pretend to be interested in the economy. Everything's a lie.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Somebody -- somebody at the table is having a cranky day. I can't imagine who that is, Gregory.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's not -- it's not a one-time event.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: There's a cool story, though, guys, that caught my attention. Because sometimes, you know, you get the Halloween candy and you don't like the candy you get. Some people gave raisins to me one year. I will never forget you. I remember who you are. But now Reese's came out with these vending machines where you can go in and you can trade your candy for better candy.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a great idea.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I think that's amazing. Why can't I think of these things? Jesse, I feel like you'd be game to go do that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's a good idea. I just don't know how it works. I mean, I would just throw, like, a rock in there.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It doesn't have to work. It's genius.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Can you throw all your apples?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: No, I think you put anything in and they give you Reese's. So everybody go down. Where is this? What's the address?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: It's in Manhattan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What's the address?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: I don't have the address. Do you guys have the address?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Are you really going?

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: No, I'm doing a segment tonight. I'm on the air. Because I'm going to eat this for dinner.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's what you have for dinner?

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: What's the worst Halloween -- did you ever go trick-or-treating and get something terrible? Like fruit.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Money. Money.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Not that fruit's not good. But money? Money is good, though.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's for UNICEF, though. That goes to the kids.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: I know, but they gave it to me.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You're supposed to give it to the kids.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right, OK, when somebody gives you money, that means they're generally drunks who didn't realize it was Halloween. So they're coming up to the door, they open the door and there's this little creatures dressed up. And they're going, "What the hell is this?" And they're saying this stuff, and they just go into their pocket and they throw money at them, thinking that's enough. And they slam the door. That was my neighborhood. That was me, actually.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know what I think, though? By about 9 p.m., Greg Gutfeld is probably not answering the door.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No way. Not at all.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Unless it's Seamless.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Unless it's -- unless it's Seamless.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: The ribs!

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, delivering my ribs.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, and he's got a little gun sticking out the window. "Hey, you kids get --"

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Not in New York, unfortunately.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: Oh, God. This segment has derailed.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So hard to get a permit these days.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: No, it isn't. It depends on who you are.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: "One More Thing" is coming up next.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Time now for "One More Thing." Mr. Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All right. My podcast is up. You go to foxnewspodcast.com, I have a great interview with Robert Wright. He's an excellent writer. We talk about tribalism. We talk about heated rhetoric and its effect, potential effect on harmful deeds. Now, check it out, you'll like it. Go to --

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Halloween Treat News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Halloween Treat News." I've got some footage of Hollywood of Alec Baldwin. He actually dressed up for Halloween as a hippo, and I think we have tape of him munching on a Halloween treat. Look at this. This is amazing. Check this out.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You know what? You might be right. That the Cincinnati Zoo and Botanical Gardens.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It's an honest mistake.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Isn't that amazing? Look at that. Eating that entire pumpkin. Hippos are just the most awesome beasts. They seem like they want to be left alone. If I were an animal, I'd be a hippo.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: You'd be a hippo.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He was good in "30 Rock," though.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He was.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: All right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So today it was just a gorgeous, beautiful day in Boston, and all the more because it was beautiful due to the Red Sox celebrating the World Series championship. The team, in true Boston style, rode duck boats from Fenway Park all the way to city hall. It was the Red Sox's fourth championship, Jesse, fourth championship in the last 15 years. And get this: Boston teams have won 11 championships in the last 17 years. You know what got my attention? There were anti-Yankees chants as the Boston fans celebrated. That rivalry, apparently, more important to Red Sox fans than beating the Dodgers.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Jesse, you know that -- Juan, they're heading to the border.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my God. It's a caravan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's the caravan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Anyway, I've got to tell you, I'm still dreaming about my Nationals. Still hoping they can win one day.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Keep dreaming. Keep dreaming.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: One day. One day.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, the Eagles beat --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You're a nationalist. I didn't know that.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's right. There we go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. OK, so my tailor is the man. His name's Giacomo. He makes me these great suits. Go check out Book a Tailor. He is the best. Check out what he does from the inside. Look at that.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exclusively tailored for "Watters World." Are we missing an apostrophe? Do I have to send this back? Come on, Giacomo! Get that right. Punctuation! And also, Watters on Martha's show tonight, "Wednesdays with Watters." We'll be talking about Oprah. We'll be talking about Kanye and Halloween. Don't miss it. Judge Jeanine.

utterances.speaker: PIRRO
utterances.utterance: All right, every year in this country, abused women suffering from domestic violence end up leaving their homes to take -- to find shelter, and they take their children with them. Timing is not something over which they have any control. They mostly leave with nothing, and when you think about the time of year, you have little kids who want to have some sense of normalcy in their lives. So in New York, My Sister's Place, which is a shelter, takes in nearly 15,000 women and children every year who seek refuge from violence. I've been on that board for 30 years. They worked to end violence in intimate relationships and combat the effects as it relates to children. The next time you go to buy a Halloween costume, buy two. Help a child who's not at home anymore. Send it to your local shelter for battered women and now visit MSPNY.org to learn how you can donate.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What a great "One More Thing."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Very nice. All right. Jedediah.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: In the spirit of Halloween, I have the "Pets of The Five," Halloween edition. That is my dog, Emma, when she was a patriot. She was also a biker girl at one point, and yes, that's right, a bee. We also have some other pictures. Dana isn't here, but you know Spike from "The Daily Briefing." He's dressed as a pirate -- oh, these are not in order, I'm sorry. That's Deb's dog, Nick, as a World Series champion Boston Red Sox champion player. We have Mike Remarco's fearless dog Lola chilling next to a skeleton. That's pretty cool. That's braver than you were in the haunted house the other day, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: BILA
utterances.utterance: And here we go, Spike from "The Daily Briefing" dressed as a pirate. Honestly, it's so cute when you dress your animals up.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
